summary: This is a September 15, 2021 letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It provides notice of the government's intent to call an FBI Computer Forensic Examiner as a witness to testify about device extractions from seized evidence, and reiterates requests for reciprocal discovery and expert witness notice from the defense.

events.title: Government Expert Witness Notice
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office formally notifies defense counsel of its intent to call an FBI Computer Forensic Examiner as a witness in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

events.title: Initial Reciprocal Discovery Request
events.description: The Government made its initial request for reciprocal expert witness notice from the defense under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16(b)(1)(C).

events.title: Initial Discovery and Witness Statement Requests
events.description: The Government made initial requests for reciprocal discovery and disclosure of prior witness statements from the defense.

keyFacts: The government plans to call an FBI Computer Forensic Examiner to testify about extracting data from devices seized via search warrants in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
The examiner's testimony will cover user information, documents, and photographs extracted from devices, including some that were clones of previous extractions.
The document reveals the government's repeated requests for reciprocal discovery from Maxwell's defense team, including expert witness notices and prior witness statements.
The FBI examiner has previously testified in other federal criminal cases, including United States v. DiTomasso, Hirst, Stash, and Kelly.
This is a procedural filing from September 2021, during the pre-trial phase of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
